div1.p: Dr. Henry R. Carter, Sanitarian, Dies

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Sun, Baltimore, September 15, 1925
div1.p:
DR. HENRY R. CARTER,
SANITARIAN, DIES

Long Illness Fatal To Assistant
Surgeon-General Of Marine
Hospital Service.

Graduated From University Of
Maryland--World Authority
On Yellow Fever.

Washington, Sept. 14 (AP).--Dr.
Henry R. Carter. Assistant Surgeon-
general of the nited States Marine
Hospital Service, died at his home here
today after a long illness.

Born in Carolina county, Virginia,
in 1852, Dr. Carter was considered one
of the foremost medical and sanitary
specialists in the country. He founded
the present maritime quarantine system
and was nominated for the Nobel prize
in connection with his discoveries in
connection with yellow fever work.

Dr. Carter is survived by two sons,
Dr. Henry R. Carter, Jr., of Birming-
ham, Ala.; Edw. Champ Carter, of
Baltimore; a brother, Charles Harrison
Carter, of Portland, Ore.; three sisters,
Mrs. Nancy Carter Redd, of Ashland,
Va.; Miss Mary Clayborne Carter,
North River Plantation, Va., and Miss
Mary C. Carter, and a daughter, Miss
Laura A. Carter.

Dr. Carter was commissioned in the
United States Marine Hospital Service,
now the Public Health Service, May 5,
1879. He served as chief quarantine
officer of Cuba from August, 1899, un-
til August, 1900, and as chief quaran-
tine officer of the Isthmian Canal Com-
mission from May, 1904, until Febru-
ary, 1905, when he became director of
hospitals of the Isthmian Canal Com-
mission, serving in this capacity from
March, 1905, until September, 1909. He
served at different times as sanitary
supervisor to the Peruvian Government
and as a member of the yellow fever
council of the international health
board of the Rockefeller Foundation
until the time of his death.

He inaugurated control measures for
malaria in the extra cantonment areas
of army camps in malarial regions dur-
ing the World War and was a member
of many scientific bodies relating to
medicine and hygiene, both American
and foreign, including the Authors' Club
of Great Britain. He formulated the
doctrine of the control of the yellow
fever bearing mosquito as the sole
method necessary for the elimination of
endemic centers of this disease.

He was intimately associated with
Surgeon-General Gorgas and Dr. Walter
Reed throughout the greater parts of
their careers, particularly in the work,
study and control of yellow fever. Dr.
Carter was graduated in medicine from
the University of Maryland and entered
the Marine Hospital Service May 5,
1879. In the fall of that year he saw
his first case of yellow fever. In 1890
Dr. Carter had proposed the disinfec-
tion of vessels from Cuban and Mexican
ports at the port of departure, so that
the time en route to the port of entry
after such disinfection could count as a
part of the “quarantine period” for
yellow fever and, by so much, lessen the
time of the detention in quarantine.
This plan was adopted.

For many months prior to his death
Dr. Carter had worked on a history of
yellow fever, which took him into many
fields of literature and history, in many
languages, and even in many dialects.
His one hope was to live until this was
completed. Three days before he was
stricken with what proved to be his last
illness he had so far completed it that
it can be finished by others and this
task will be undertaken by his daughter,
Miss Laura Carter.

Funeral services will be held at 10
o'clock Wednesday morning. These
will be first at the Westmoreland and
later at St. Margaret's Church. Arch-
deacon Sterling Clayborne, of Sewanee,
Tenn., and the Rev. Dr. Smith, of St.
Margaret's Church, will officiate. The
body will be taken to Ashland, Va., for
burial.
